lines.text: [York plans the rescue of children held prisoner by Apaches]
Is it dark enough for you to get in there?
With two men I pick, sir.
Two men you pick? I know you're a excellent judge of horse flesh, Trooper Tyree. You proved that when you stole my horse. But how are you as a judge of men for a dangerous mission?
I consider myself a good judge of men I trust, sir.
You said it, soldier, that's enough for me!
Ramrod, wreckage and ruin, still the same Kirby York.
Special privileges to special born, still the same Kathleen.
[toasting]
To my only rival, the United States Cavalry.
[Lt. Col. York lectures new recruits]

I don't want you men to be fooled about what's coming up for you. Torture, at least that. The War Department promised me 180 men. They sent me eighteen. You are the eighteen... so each of you will have to do the work of ten men. If you fail, I'll have you spread-eagled on a wagon wheel. If you desert, you'll be found, tracked down and broken into bits. That is all.
But put out of your mind any romantic ideas that it's a way of glory. It's a life of suffering and hardship, an uncompromising devotion to your oath and your duty.
But he must learn that a man's word to anything, even his own destruction, is his honor.
I'm going to issue you an order and give it to you personally. I want you to cross the Rio Grande, hit the Apache and burn him out. I'm tired of hit-and-run. I'm sick of diplomatic hide-and-seek.
Any liquor in this village?
Mucho tequila. They were slugging it down copious like when I left.
Drums? Singing?
Yes, sir.
Vengeance dance. They'll dance until dawn.
I'm Hungary... Beans? Didn't nobody ever tell the army that they grew beef in this part of the country?

[laughing]
Not lately. We'll be on cold rations for three days.

[to the troop]
Is there any man here from Texas?
Yes sir; I'm from Texas. Name's Boone... Daniel Boone.
Daniel Boone? That sounds familiar, don't it?
[looks through circulars]
Name's Tyree!

[breaking up a solders' fight]
Qincannon, what started this?
I refuse to answer sir... respectfully.
Heinze?
I refuse to answer, sir.
Yorke?
No, sir.
Soldiers' fight, eh? Carry on.
[leaves the site]
Sorry, soldier.
Thanks, Heinze.

[breaking up soldier's fight]
Break it up! Who started this?

[indicating Heinze]
This fella talked derogatory about the boy's pappy.
Yeah, he called him the teacher's pet of a chuckle-headed Mick sergeant. What's that mean, doc?

[to Heinze]
Oh, you said that, did ya?
Yes, I did.
And did ya mean it?
Yes I did.

[exasperated]
A chuckle... what was that?
Chuckle-headed Mick sergeant.
And you meant it?
Yes I did.
Get 'er done, Reb.
Hey, Mister... what time do they blow the horn around here for people t' eat?
[repeated line]
Yo.
[repeated line]
You'll get busted for this, Quincannon.
At Chapultopec, my father, your grandfather, shot for cowardice the son of a United States senator

[Jeff holds his salute]
What are you waiting for?
Trooper Yorke expects his salute to be retuned, sir. Army regulations.
[Quincannon laughs]
Quincannon!
[Col. Yorke rises, salutes]
Did any of youse ever ride a horse?
Yeah, some.

[admiringly]
Boy 'o, horsemen!
Seems t' me they make a lotta fuss about jumpin' a horse over some sticks.
That's a six-foot jump, Travis!
Yankee justice! Arresting that nice young man and charging him with manslaughter, while they promote arsonists to be Sergeant Majors!

[referring to Margaret Mary]
I'm startin' to wonder whose side that kid's on - theirs or ours.
